A diaphragmatic hernia is a birth defect, which is an abnormality that occurs before birth as a fetus is forming in the mother's uterus. An opening is present in the diaphragm (the muscle that separates the chest cavity from the abdominal cavity). 1 Bochdalek hernia-A Bochdalek hernia involves an opening on the left side of the diaphragm. 2  The stomach and intestines usually move up into the chest cavity. 3  Morgagni hernia-A Morgagni hernia involves an opening on the right side of the diaphragm. 4  The liver and intestines usually move up into the chest cavity.

A Bochdalek hernia is a congenital abnormality in which an opening exists in the infant’s diaphragm, allowing normally intra-abdominal organs (particularly the stomach and intestines) to protrude into the thoracic cavity. Babies who are born with a Bochdalek hernia are more than likely to have another birth defect caused by the hernia. About twenty percent of those children born with a Bochdalek hernia, also have a congenital heart defect. In addition, infants born with this condition may also have other abnormalities.

A Bochdalek hernia is a potentially life-threatening congenital defect in which the diaphragm fails to close correctly. As a result, it is possible for abdominal organs and other tissues to push upward into the chest cavity.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a congenital malformation (birth defect) of the diaphragm. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia; other types include Morgagni hernia, diaphragm eventration and central tendon defects of the diaphragm.
